results.title: Birth of Dawn
results.brief_description:
Hannah Brontë’s Birth of Dawn explores the cycle of life, birth, death and rebirth through the lens of the femme body. The sun, reimagined as a pregnant belly, symbolises the moment before new life enters the world. The work invites us to consider the Earth as a living, breathing body and questions how we move across it.

Set on a planet yet to experience its first dawn, this dreamscape merges ancient and futuristic landscapes, free from man-made objects. The inhabitants communicate through movement and telepathic frequencies projected through the soundscape. Having evolved beyond language, they experience every emotion that comes with growth – pain and pleasure ripple across each frame.

Birth of Dawn transports you into the present moment through bass-heavy waves, where past and future merge into one continuous cycle. There is no beginning or end here – only the infinite potential of new life and transformation.

There is nothing more science fiction than nature itself.

Created on the unceded lands of Yugambeh, Arakwal and Bundjalung Country

constellations_primary.name: Scripture for spiritual connections and sci-fi futures
constellations_primary.description: Connections between people, animals and the environment in sci-fi stories, videogames, art and film.

results.description:
The sun rises and sets, followed by the moon’s rotation each day — there is always a new beginning. The sun is reimagined as a pregnant belly, the moment before new life enters this rotation. If we treat the earth as another breathing body, how do we move across it? The present is pregnant with the future. You are transported to a planet that has yet to experience its first Birth of Dawn.

Birth and death rituals are explored through the framework of the femme body. The cycle of being born, flourishing, rotting, decaying, and beginning again repeats within dreamscapes untouched by man-made objects. There is no beginning nor end to this portal. These landscapes are both ancient and futuristic, their immense knowledge and technology seamlessly woven into every ecosystem. There is nothing more science fiction than nature itself.

The inhabitants experience every emotion that accompanies growth—pain and pleasure ripple across each frame. They communicate through movement and telepathic frequencies, having evolved beyond language. As they prepare for birth, their internal thoughts are projected through the soundscape, carrying us from moonlight to daybreak, over and over. Swimming through bass-heavy tides, this work seeks to transport you not forward or backward, but to expand you into the present moment, where past, present, and future are intertwined as one.

“We rot and become god again. Impregnated with possibility, I birth new dawns. Open. Fecund. Cycles. Spiral up, up, up with me. I see you. I see you in the ocean; I see you in the lava. Stay open. Stay tender every chance you get. Split your heart wide open and let it expand with me. Let’s run!”

  • Hannah Brontë

Created on the unceded lands of Yugambeh, Arakwal and Bundjalung Country

Costume materials: Salvaged fishing net, fish scales, abalone, clam, pippi, cowrie, mother of pearl, stingray bone, wire, muslin, silk, stocking, natural dyes, wool, silicone, pearls, glass, wire, palm bark, cotton twine.

Costume contribution by Megan Hanson from previous work

Videographer: Aidan Rice

Sound: Jesse Koroi

Vocals: Mayan Hennemeyer

Editor: Kate O’Sullivan

Models: Kel Knox, Clea Prat, Lisa Kelly , Mayatu Nova, Sasskia Sassen , Drea Lam, Taree Sansbury, Naomi Appo, Eilla Appo, Hannah Brontë

results.title: At the Foot of the Arapiles
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet the business owners and locals who call Natimuk home and wouldn’t want to live anywhere else. Even though locals consider it to be full of ‘climbers’ and ‘arty-types’, they recognise Natimuk, in western Victoria, as an active and diverse community and wouldn’t have it any other way.

results.title: Dave Jones and his Giant Puppet
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dave Jones is an animator who moved to Natimuk about 2001, follow him as he works on an ambitious live projection project involving a 14 metre high puppet, which will be suspended from the town grain silos.

results.title: The Natimuk Rock Climbers
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Jessica Scott and ACMI
results.brief_description: Louise Shepherd and Keith ‘Noddy’ Lockwood reminisce, tell anecdotes and reveal what makes a “mountain goat” tick, and how Mt Arapiles, in western Victoria, has shaped Natimuk’s destiny as an international destination for climbers.

results.title: Chris Masters: Screen Worlds Spotlight interview

video_links.name: Chris Masters: Screen Worlds Spotlight interview

results.brief_description: An interview with journalist Chris Masters created for Screen Worlds at ACMI. Chris Masters is an investigative journalist who has won several Gold Walkley awards and reported for the ABC’s “Four Corners”.

results.title: Australian gazette. No. 3
results.brief_description: This reel consists of 7 magazine items, including snapshots of the Fitzroy Gardens, a trip to Seal Rock by boat, Kangaroos at Wilson’s Prom, beehives shot in close-up and some prize footage of a motorcycle race on a track around the outside of the Exhibition Buildings. There is also some surprising early experimental filming of Flinders Street, and traffic and crowds on Swanston Street. One amazing shot appears upside-down and then mid-way proceeds to turn upright and show the traffic and people travelling backwards. Footage is then sped up for a cable car ride down a main street. No credits available.

results.title: The Exorcist
results.creator_credit: William Friedkin, William Peter Blatty and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: The Exorcist occupies a central position in the history of horror films, an almost sadistically malevolent experience in terror. Regan (Linda Blair) is a young girl entering puberty and she becomes possessed by the spirit of an ancient demon. Her mother (Ellen Burstyn) finds that there is no assistance in the scientific pragmatism of the modern world and she hesitantly turns to the occult rites of Catholicism and Orthodoxy in order to rid her daughter of the monster. The exorcism scenes attain a disturbing authenticity and they are based on the official Catholic Church rites of exorcism. “The Exorcist” is a film that feeds on our most intimate fears and terrors and not a film for the easily frightened. Stars Max Van Sydow as Father Merrin. Based on the book by William Peter Blatty. Mercedes McCambridge is the voice of the Devil. Part of Tubular Bell by Mike Oldfield used on the soundtrack.

results.title: Lykke Li: Sadness is a Blessing

constellations_other.name: Weaving a Dark Web
constellations_other.description:
In contemporary Hollywood cinema, children's films often align with comedy and musical genres. However, harking back to the days of European fairytales (and certainly beyond), children's stories are historically dark in tone and were written for both children and adult audiences alike. 
With an apocalyptic threat looming large, Moomins and the Comet Chase veers more into darker territory. However, it is the talented voice cast that conjures some connections to some pure cinema darkness.

results.title: Rihanna: Bitch Better Have My Money

constellations_other.name: Dystopian Futures & Horrific Pasts
constellations_other.description: For an industry that leans strongly toward happy endings, it's interesting to note that a lot of futures that are speculated in film are dystopic.  However we don't need to look too far to find horrors in the past and present.
